result.execSummary:
The defendant Craig M Piquette was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Attempt 1st-Degree Intentional Homicide [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Use of a Dangerous Weapon, Repeater], a class B felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.01(1)(a).
  • Armed Robbery [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Repeater], a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.32(2).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Length of confinement and length of extended supervision for a total length of 30 years bifurcated sentence.
Consecutive to: current sentence

superMiscConds.notes: Defendant must pay all outstanding fees and court obligations.  If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment. DNA sample previously provided, however, defendant must pay mandatory DNA surcharge.   CORRECTED 12-28-2016:  Court costs were waived by the Court.
No alcohol, random UA's at discretion of agent.
No controlled substances, random UA's at discretion of agent.

Transition into a sober living facility for 6 months.  Take medications as prescribed.  Defendant must obey all rules and regulations of probation.  Firearm warning given.  Ineligible voting notice and acknowledgement.

AMENDED 1/13/2016 to add restitution.
  It is the court's intention that the Department of Corrections can take 25% from all money received for the benefit of the inmate while he is incarcerated to be applied to restitution owing to the victim.   If supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.

AMENDED 09-23-2016 - TO MARK RESTITUTION JOINT AND SEVERAL
